procedure.title: Food Manufacturing, Processing and Storage Pest Management Program
procedure.goal: To implement an Integrated Pest Management (IPM) program in a food facility to control pests while minimizing health, economic, and environmental hazards.

steps.note: Maintain short grass, paved access, proper drainage, and place night-lights at least 30 feet from doors.
Seal openings, screen windows, use tight-fitting doors, and eliminate voids or harborage points.

steps.action: establish and run an in-plant sanitation program
steps.note: Involves organizing a committee, conducting regular inspections, documenting deficiencies, and ensuring follow-up.
Use visual inspections and traps to detect pests, identify them, and determine the extent of any problems.
A written procedure is required by law. Check vehicles and products for signs of infestation before acceptance.
Use a combination of non-chemical controls (traps, air curtains) and pesticide treatments (space, spot, crack/crevice, fumigation) as needed.

steps.action: manage pests in processing and packaging areas
steps.note: This is the most critical area. Use traps, sanitation, and appropriate pesticide treatments (space, spot, crack/crevice) while protecting exposed food.
Ensure vehicles are clean and free of infestation before loading the final product.

constraints.text: Pesticides are often used as a last resort, after preventive and non-chemical options.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspection access.
In food areas, residual application is permitted only as a crack and crevice treatment.
Tracking powders cannot be used where they might contaminate food or food surfaces.
Use tamper-proof bait stations to protect bait and prevent access by non-target animals.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection as indicated on the pesticide label, especially for space treatments.
It is illegal to use a pesticide in a manner inconsistent with its labeling. Always read and follow label directions.
A food product must have a tolerance for any pesticide residue it contains, or the product is considered adulterated.
